Version 2.3.27

Notice success: Page caching is currently active.

Shared UI

Example Plugin GitHub Repository

Usage

This page serves as a showcase for the Shared UI library used internally for WPMU DEV plugins.

npm install @wpmudev/shared-ui

Depending on your plugin's setup, you can either include the whole production ready css and js files or explicitly import needed sass partials & individual js components into your plugins build (recommended).

Requirements

In order to avoid conflicts with other versions of this library, we are using a versioned body class in the format .sui-x-x-x where hyphens are replacing the periods of the current shared-ui package version. When using the shared-ui library in your plugin, make sure you are adding a body class with the same shared-ui version you are using.

add_filter( 'admin_body_class', 'admin_body_classes' );
function admin_body_classes( $classes ) {

	$classes .= 'sui-2-3-27';

	return $classes;

}

Page Heading

Page Headings contain the h1 and have the options of actions left and right.

Example Heading

<div class="sui-header">
	<h1 class="sui-header-title">Example Heading</h1>
	<div class="sui-actions-left">
		<label class="sui-toggle">
			<input type="checkbox">
			<span class="sui-toggle-slider"></span>
		</label>
	</div>
	<div class="sui-actions-right">
		<button class="sui-button sui-button-ghost"><i class="sui-icon-academy"></i> View Documentation</button>
	</div>
</div>

Boxes

Boxes are the primary visual containers. They should be used to hold related information.

  • Basic Box
  • Settings Box
  • Status Box
  • Search Box
  • Message Box
  • Documentation

Message Box

This normal message box usually contains: image, title and text.

This large message box usually contains: image, text and button(s).

Base Structure This white-box contains several box-elements depending on what you need. 
<div class="sui-box">

	...

</div>
Sticky Box When scrolling down this will stick the sui-box below the WP admin bar until you reach the end of the containing div.

An examle of this being used is shown in the Status Box tab.

<div class="sui-box sui-box-sticky">

	...

</div>
Box Header This is an element for sui-box. 
<div class="sui-box-header">

	<!-- Box title with icon -->
	<h3 class="sui-box-title">
		<i class="sui-icon-hummingbird" aria-hidden="true"></i> Basic Box
	</h3>

	<!-- Elements aligned to left, next to title -->
	<div class="sui-actions-left">
		...
	</div>

	<!-- Elements aligned to right -->
	<div class="sui-actions-right">
		...
	</div>

</div>
Box Content This is an element for sui-box. 
<div class="sui-box-body">

	...

</div>
Box Settings This is an element for sui-box-body.

In case you need a flushed settings, add sui-flushed next to sui-box-settings-row class.

<div class="sui-box-settings-row">

	<div class="sui-box-settings-col-1">
		<span class="sui-settings-label">Settings Label</span>
		<span class="sui-description">Some description you want to add.</span>
	</div>

	<div class="sui-box-settings-col-2">
		...
	</div>

</div>
Box Status Commonly used on plugins that make use of builders.   NOTE: This is a lonely element inside sui-box. 
<div class="sui-box-status">

	<div class="sui-status">

		<div class="sui-status-module">Status <span class="sui-tag">Draft</span></div>

		<div class="sui-status-changes"><i class="sui-icon-update" aria-hidden="true"></i> Unsaved changes</div>

	</div>

	<div class="sui-actions">

		<button id="forminator-module-save" class="sui-button">
			<span class="sui-loading-text">
				<i class="sui-icon-save" aria-hidden="true"></i>
				<span class="button-text">Save Draft</span>
			</span>
			<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
		</button>

		<button id="forminator-module-publish" class="sui-button sui-button-blue">
			<span class="sui-loading-text">
				<i class="sui-icon-web-globe-world" aria-hidden="true"></i>
				<span class="button-text">Publish</span>
			</span>
			<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
		</button>

	</div>

</div>
Box Message Commonly used to show an "empty" or "call-to-action" message.

In case you need a box with large margins use sui-message-lg next to sui-message class.

<div class="sui-box sui-message">

	<img src="image.png"
		srcset="image.png 1x, image@2x.png 2x"
		class="sui-image"
		aria-hidden="true" />

	<div class="sui-message-content">
		<h2>... title ...</h2>
		<p>... content ...</p>
		<p><button class="sui-button">Button</button></p>
	</div>

</div>

Selectors Box

This element is commonly used on dialogs and always have a light-gray background to highlight its white-box items. The main purpose of it is allow users to select one or more options.

  • Default
  • Vertical
  • The Grid
  • Documentation
Simple By default the box selectors are aligned horizontal, based on its icon + text position, and text is always left aligned.
Complex There are some cases where you gonna need to include a description for the items.
Simple You can vertical align box selectors where its text will always be center aligned and icon will be placed on top of text.
Complex There are some cases where you gonna need to include a description for the items.
Auto-Width Columns Not matter how many elements are, they all will be placed in one row.
1 Column The elements will occupy the full-width of the row.
2 Columns The elements will have 50% width and will be placed a max of two elements per row.
3 Columns Elements will ocuppy a third of a row, allowing a max of 3 elements to be placed per row.
4 Columns Elements will ocuppy a fourth of a row, allowing a max of 4 elements to be placed per row.
5 Columns Elements will ocuppy a fifth of a row, allowing a max of 5 elements to be placed per row.
Base Structure 
<div class="sui-box-selectors">

	<ul>

		<li><label for="" class="sui-box-selector">
			<input type="radio"
				id="" />
			<span>Element text</span>
		</label></li>

		<li><label for="" class="sui-box-selector">
			<input type="radio"
				id="" />
			<span>Element text</span>
		</label></li>

	</ul>

</div>
Elements Structure

To get a vertical element, it's necessary to add sui-box-selector-vertical class next to sui-box-selector.

<!-- Single Choice (Radio)
	 When you need user to pick one option only -->
<li><label for="item-id" class="sui-box-selector">
	<input type="radio"
		name="item-radio-input"
		id="item-id"
		checked="checked" />
	<span><i class="sui-icon-info" aria-hidden="true"></i> Item Name</span>
	<span>Here comes some description for your item.
</label></li>

<!-- Multiple Choice (Checkbox)
	 When you allow user to select more than one option -->
<li><label for="item-id" class="sui-box-selector">
	<input type="checkbox"
		name="item-checkbox-input"
		id="item-id"
		checked="checked" />
	<span><i class="sui-icon-info" aria-hidden="true"></i> Item Name</span>
	<span>Here comes some description for your item.
</label></li>
Grid Variations 
<!-- Auto Width Columns -->
<div class="sui-box-selectors">
	<ul> ... </ul>
</div>

<!-- 1 Column Per Row -->
<div class="sui-box-selectors sui-box-selectors-col-1">
	<ul> ... </ul>
</div>

<!-- 2 Columns Per Row -->
<div class="sui-box-selectors sui-box-selectors-col-2">
	<ul> ... </ul>
</div>

<!-- 3 Columns Per Row -->
<div class="sui-box-selectors sui-box-selectors-col-3">
	<ul> ... </ul>
</div>

<!-- 4 Columns Per Row -->
<div class="sui-box-selectors sui-box-selectors-col-4">
	<ul> ... </ul>
</div>

<!-- 5 Columns Per Row -->
<div class="sui-box-selectors sui-box-selectors-col-5">
	<ul> ... </ul>
</div>

Builder Box

This element is commonly used on projects like Hustle, Branda or Forminator where you let user to build, for example, an opt-in form.

  • Samples
  • Documentation
Empty Builder The first state of the builder where you can display an insert button along with simple message.
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Builder Fields In this sample you can see the most complex variation for builder field, but you can modify it as pleasure by removing or ignoring elements from the markup that you won't need.
Element
Element with image
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Accordion Fields Some times you gonna need to mix builder fields with accordion to display extra settings or content for the field.
Element
Extra settings go here...
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Field Complex Header Some projects require extra settings on box builder fields, for those cases you are going to find useful this element variation.
Show embed if of the following conditions are met.
Apply on
Element
Extra settings go here...
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Builder Footer Some times you gonna need to add static fields that user won't be able to remove.
Element
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Static Element
Builder Flushed Some times you need to make builder borders reach its container edges.
Element
Nothing has been added yet. Click on "+ Insert Button" to add your first element.
Static Element
Base Structure 
<div class="sui-box-builder">

	<!-- Header -->
	<div class="sui-box-builder-header">

		<button class="sui-button sui-button-purple">
			<i class="sui-icon-plus" aria-hidden="true"></i>
			Insert Button
		</button>

	</div>

	<!-- Body / Content -->
	<div class="sui-box-builder-body">

		<div class="sui-builder-fields">

			<!-- Insert builder field(s) here -->

		</div>

		<button class="sui-button sui-button-dashed">
			<i class="sui-icon-plus" aria-hidden="true"></i>
			Insert Button
		</button>

		<span class="sui-box-builder-message">Builder message</span>

	</div>

	<!-- Footer -->
	<div class="sui-box-builder-footer">

		<!-- Inser static field(s) here -->

	</div>

</div>
Base Field 
<div class="sui-builder-field">

	<div class="sui-builder-field-label">

		<i class="sui-icon-check" aria-hidden="true"></i>

		<span>Element</span>

	</div>

	<!-- Include here field element(s) -->

</div>
Field Elements You can include different elements to builder fields, from buttons to border separators.

Make use of sui-hover-show class on an element if you need to show it only when user hovers on sui-builder-field.

Icon button
<button class="sui-button-icon">
	<i class="sui-icon-widget-settings-config" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Open settings</span>
</button>
Dropdown button
<div class="sui-dropdown">
	<button class="sui-button-icon sui-dropdown-anchor">
		<i class="sui-icon-widget-settings-config" aria-hidden="true"></i>
		<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Open settings</span>
	</button>
	<ul>
		<li><button>Edit field</button></li>
		<li><button>Clone field</button></li>
		<li><button>Remove field</button></li>
	</ul>
</div>
Field notice
<div class="sui-builder-field-notice"
	data-tooltip="Field information goes here">
	<i class="sui-icon-info" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</div>
Field elements separator
A simple border that's gonna keep content properly separated. 
<div class="sui-builder-field-border" aria-hidden="true"></div>
Drag and drop Some times builders allow to re-organize fields.

Include the following class sui-can-move next to sui-builder-field to make sure it uses move pointer.

<div class="sui-builder-field">

	<i class="sui-icon-drag" aria-hidden="true"></i>

	<div class="sui-builder-field-label">

		<i class="sui-icon-check" aria-hidden="true"></i>

		<span>Element</span>

	</div>

	<!-- Include here field element(s) -->

</div>

Buttons

Buttons are used everywhere across all designs, come in two different sizes and have many variations.

  • Basic Structure
  • Color Buttons
  • With Icon
  • Outlined
  • Filled
  • Large
  • Disabled
  • Loading
  • Compound
  • Input + Button
  • Dashed
Basic Structure There are two types of buttons: regular and icon. 1. Regular, allows you to have text and combine it with an icon if necessary. 2. Icon, it's done to show an icon only without text.
Regular Button This is the base markup for any button that contains text. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button">
	Default
</button>
Icon Button This is the base markup for any button that has an icon only. Remember you can't use it with text, and even if you try it will be cut-off. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Icon button
	</span>
</button>

To colorize buttons you just need to add sui-button-{color_name} class, replacing {color_name} with the color you desire.

Color Buttons Aside default, which is the main color for any button, six more exist: 1. Blue 2. Green 3. Red 4. Orange 5. Yellow 6. Purple
Regular Button There are some cases when you gonna need buttons with specific colors, to achieve this you can add sui-button-{color_name} class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-blue">
	Blue Button
</button>
Icon Button There are some cases when you gonna need buttons with specific colors, to achieve this you can add sui-button-{color_name} class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon sui-button-blue">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Blue icon button
	</span>
</button>
Button With Icon
Regular Button You can place the icon by default at left of the text, or use sui-button-icon-right to add the correct spacing when you place it at right of the text. 
<!-- Left Icon (Default) -->
<button type="button" class="sui-button">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	Button with left icon
</button>

<!-- Right Icon -->
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-icon-right">
	Button with right icon
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</button>
Icon Button By default this buttons variation must have an icon, reason why you won't need any special class for this. Just remember it doesn't allow text, just one icon. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Icon button
	</span>
</button>

Outlined are buttons with border and transparent background on its default state. For regular buttons just add sui-button-ghost class, while icon buttons gonna need sui-button-outlined class.

Outlined Buttons
Regular Button This variation can come with border only and transparent background. For those cases you can make use of sui-button-ghost class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-ghost">
	Ghost Button
</button>
Icon Button This variation will add a border to the button and increase a bit its width. When you need it, just add sui-button-outlined class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon sui-button-outlined">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Icon button outlined
	</span>
</button>

Only icon buttons have this variation and you need sui-button-filled class.

Filled Buttons
Regular Button By default this buttons variation it is filled, reason why you won't need any special class for this. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button">
	Button
</button>
Icon Button By default icon buttons have a transparent background, but in case you need some color use sui-button-filled class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon sui-button-filled">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Icon button filled
	</span>
</button>

To make large (bigger) buttons, you just need to add sui-button-lg class.

Large Buttons
Regular Button There are some cases when you gonna need to make use of bigger buttons, to achieve this you can add sui-button-lg class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-lg">
	Ghost Button
</button>
Icon Button There are some cases when you gonna need to make use of bigger buttons, to achieve this you can add sui-button-lg class. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon sui-button-lg">
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Icon button large
	</span>
</button>
Disabled Buttons
Regular Button As simple as it sounds, only add disabled attribute to the element. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button" disabled>
	Button Text
</button>
Icon Button As simple as it sounds, only add disabled attribute to the element. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon" disabled>
	<i class="sui-icon-academy" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Icon button disabled
	</span>
</button>

For loading (on load) state to work, you just need to add sui-button-onload class after click, if you need to return to default state, just remove the class.

Loading Buttons
Regular Button When you need to add a spinning wheel after clicking the button to make users feel like something is being saved or loaded. 
<!-- STATE: Default -->
<button type="button" class="sui-button">
	<span class="sui-loading-text">Button</span>
	<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</button>

<!-- STATE: On Load (Loading) -->
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-onload">
	<span class="sui-loading-text">Button</span>
	<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</button>
Icon Button When you need to add a spinning wheel after click to the button making users feel like something is being saved or loaded. 
<!-- STATE: Default -->
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon">
	<span class="sui-loading-text" aria-hidden="true">
		<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
	</span>
	<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Button text
	</span>
</button>

<!-- STATE: On Load (Loading) -->
<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon sui-button-onload">
	<span class="sui-loading-text" aria-hidden="true">
		<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
	</span>
	<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">
		Button text
	</span>
</button>

Only regular buttons have a compound variation because it needs a mix of text and icon. In desktop you should have text or a mix between text and icon, while on mobiles you should have an icon only.

Compound Buttons In some parts of the design you gonna find buttons that transform into icon only buttons when they are visualized in small screens.
Regular Button This is the basic structure of a compound button, text on desktop and icon on mobile. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-compound">
	<span class="sui-compound-desktop" aria-hidden="">
		<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
		Compound Button
	</span>
	<span class="sui-compound-mobile" aria-hidden="">
		<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
	</span>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Compound Button</span>
</button>
Regular Button – On Load There are times where you gonna need to make use of a compound-loading button. Here's a sample: 
<!-- STATE: Default -->
<button class="sui-button sui-button-compound">
	<span class="sui-loading-text" aria-hidden="true">
		<span class="sui-compound-desktop">
			<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
			Compound Button
		</span>
		<span class="sui-compound-mobile">
			<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
		</span>
	</span>
	<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Compound Button</span>
</button>

<!-- STATE: On Load (Loading) -->
<button class="sui-button sui-button-compound sui-button-onload">
	<span class="sui-loading-text" aria-hidden="true">
		<span class="sui-compound-desktop">
			<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
			Compound Button
		</span>
		<span class="sui-compound-mobile">
			<i class="sui-icon-academy"></i>
		</span>
	</span>
	<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Compound Button</span>
</button>
Input With Button There are times when you need to mix input and buttons in a same row.
Default In this variation button is placed next to input and is commonly used with a large button. 
<div class="sui-with-button">
	<input
		type="text"
		class="sui-form-control"
	/>
	<button class="sui-button sui-button-lg">Button</button>
</div>
Inside Buttons can also be placed inside the input, to achieve that just need to add sui-inside class. 
<div class="sui-with-button sui-inside">
	<input
		type="text"
		class="sui-form-control"
	/>
	<button class="sui-button">Button</button>
</div>

There are times when the button width exceeds 80px like the example below (or even if it's smaller than that), for those cases just add inline padding-right: {size}px; styles to make sure input text isn't hidden behind button.

To calculate {size} make sure you sum button size and spacing (5px). Regular buttons have left and right spacing, while large buttons have left spacing only.

Dashed Button Used with selectors box this button has a width of 100% and default height of 60px. 
<button type="button" class="sui-button sui-button-dashed">
	<i class="sui-icon-plus" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	Dashed Button
</button>
You can add the class sui-lg to give the button a height of 70px.

Code Snippets

Code snippets are to be used to display code to the user and allow them to copy to clipboard.

If you are using individual js components, code-snippet.js is required for copy to clipboard functionality.

We use the library clipboard.js to allow code snippet copied.

Any element with the class sui-code-snippet will be instantiated SUICodeSnippet and the instance is accessible using jQuery selector like $('selector').data('SUICodeSnippet'). 

<IfModule mod_rewrite.c>
RewriteEngine On
RewriteBase /
RewriteRule ^index\.php$ - [L]
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-d
RewriteRule . /index.php [L]
</IfModule>
<pre class="sui-code-snippet">
	...
</pre>

Without copy button:

<IfModule mod_rewrite.c>
RewriteEngine On
RewriteBase /
RewriteRule ^index\.php$ - [L]
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-d
RewriteRule . /index.php [L]
</IfModule>
<pre class="sui-code-snippet sui-no-copy">
	...
</pre>

Javascript Instantiation

// initiate all sui-code-snippet
SUI.suiCodeSnippet();

// initiate single sui-code-snippet
$('.my-selector').SUICodeSnippet();

JS API

// initiate with custom copy text
$('.my-selector').SUICodeSnippet({
	'copyText': 'Copy .htaccess', // button text
	'copiedText': '.htaccess copied', // tooltip text when copied
});

// get Clipboard.JS inistance
const clipboard = $('.my-selector').data('SUICodeSnippet').getClipboardJs();
clipboard.on('success', function(e){
	alert('Copied!');
});

// destroy instance
$('.my-selector').data('SUICodeSnippet').destroy();

Grid

The grid system should be used to layout boxes & forms. The grid requires a minimum of 2 components, the columns, and the row that wraps the columns.

For equally spaced columns that stay inline at all breakpoints, you can use the basic .sui-col:

.sui-col
.sui-col
<div class="sui-row">
	<div class="sui-col">
		...
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col">
		...
	</div>
</div>

For more control over column behavior for different breakpoints, there is a 12 column grid similar to Bootstrap 3 naming conventions & behavior but powered by flexbox instead of floats:

.sui-col-md-3
.sui-col-md-6
.sui-col-md-3
<div class="sui-row">
	<div class="sui-col-md-3">
		...
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col-md-6">
		...
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col-md-3">
		...
	</div>
</div>

Examples:

.sui-col-lg-3
.sui-col-lg-3
.sui-col-lg-3
.sui-col-lg-3
.sui-col-sm-9
.sui-col-sm-3
.sui-col-lg-4
.sui-col-lg-4 .sui-col-lg-offset-4
.sui-col-sm-8 .sui-col-sm-offset-4
.sui-col-sm-7 .sui-col-sm-offset-5

You can reverse the order of the columns by adding the class .sui-reverse to the .sui-row element.

Original:

1
2
3
<div class="sui-row">
	<div class="sui-col">
		1
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col">
		2
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col">
		3
	</div>
</div>

Reversed:

1
2
3
<div class="sui-row sui-reverse">
	<div class="sui-col">
		1
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col">
		2
	</div>
	<div class="sui-col">
		3
	</div>
</div>

Use a single or combination of the available classes for toggling content across viewport breakpoints.

Extra small devices Phones (<480px) Small devices Tablets (≥480px) Medium devices Desktops (≥800px) Large devices Desktops (≥1200px)
.sui-hidden-xs Hidden Visible Visible Visible
.sui-hidden-sm Visible Hidden Visible Visible
.sui-hidden-md Visible Visible Hidden Visible
.sui-hidden-lg Visible Visible Visible Hidden

Examples:

.sui-hidden-md .sui-hidden-sm .sui-hidden-xs
.sui-hidden-md
.sui-hidden-lg

Progress Bars

Progress bars can be dynamically moved by changing the width of .sui-progress-bar span with js.

The markup changed slightly in SUI 2.3.9. Take a look at Documentation section and update your code.

  • Samples
  • Documentation

Progress Bars

When we are able to indicate how long a process will take, and show the progress accurately we use progress bars to display this.

Default The standard state when a process is in progress. In general, it’s great to update both the progress and status as often as possible (every few seconds).
50%
Status...
Hover In most cases we allow the user to abort the process, and this can be done using the icon/button on the right of the progess bar.
50%
Status...
No Cancel When we can’t let the user cancel the process.
50%
Status...

Progress Bars

<div class="sui-progress-block">

	<div class="sui-progress">

		<span class="sui-progress-icon" aria-hidden="true">
			<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading"></i>
		</span>

		<span class="sui-progress-text">
			<span>50%</span>
		</span>

		<div class="sui-progress-bar" aria-hidden="true">
			<span style="width: 50%"></span>
		</div>

	</div>

	<button class="sui-button-icon sui-tooltip"
		data-tooltip="Cancel">
		<i class="sui-icon-close" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	</button>

</div>

<div class="sui-progress-state">
	<span>Status...</span>
</div>

Upgrade Page

This is a full upgrade page example which will be applied linked from the free plugin sidebar menu.

Upgrade page uses reviews.js to dynamically update the reviews stats so you'll need to include this file.

To load an image into upgrade page header, you need to override the variables $upgrade-image: 'image-path'; $upgrade-image-mobile: 'mobile-image-path';.

Upgrade to Hummingbird Pro

Get Hummingbird Pro for our full WordPress speed optimization suite, including uptime monitoring, enhanced hosted file minification, and white label reports for clients.

Plus – you’ll get WPMU DEV membership, which includes our award winning Smush Pro plugin for image optimization, 24/7 live WordPress support, and unlimited usage of all our premium plugins.

- / 5.0 rating from - customers
Reviews.io

Pro Features

Upgrading to Pro will get you the following benefits.

Whitelabel automated reporting

You’ll get automated email reporting of your site’s performance (or if you have a multisite network, we’ve still got you covered!). You can even whitelabel this for your clients, and have the reports sent straight to them. You’re informed and look great, and we do the work for you.

Uptime monitoring

Make sure you know when your site is available with Hummingbird’s Pro uptime monitoring. We’ll notify you by email if there’s a problem with any of your WordPress sites loading, and we’ll even check your site’s average response time, and give you a rolling average, so you always know how well your site is performing.

Enhanced file minification with CDN

You’ll get enhanced file minification, with 2x the compression. Plus, for maximum speed, you can load your files from our global WPMU DEV CDN – instead of your server. Make your files smaller, and then load them faster with Hummingbird Pro.

Smush Pro for the best image optimization

Hummingbird Pro + Smush Pro gives you the fastest possible WordPress site: Hummingbird’s performance optimization + Smush’s award-winning image optimization. It’s a powerful combination which your visitors, customers, and search engines will love.

Premium WordPress plugins

You’ll get our full suite of premium WordPress plugins, making sure from Security to Backups to Marketing and SEO you’ve got all the WordPress solutions you can possible need. You get unlimited usage on unlimited sites, and can join the millions using our plugins.

Manage unlimited WordPress sites

You can manage unlimited WordPress sites with automated updates, backups, security, and performance! – checks, all in one place. All of this can be whitelabeled for your clients, and you even get our 24/7 live WordPress support.

24/7 live WordPress support

We can’t stress this enough: our outstanding WordPress support is available with live chat 24/7, and we’ll help you with absolutely any WordPress issue – not just our products. It’s an expert WordPress team on call for you, whenever you need them.

Documentation

If you want to perform some actions, like open a menu or adding a link, inside accordion items header remember to add sui-accordion-item-action to the element, that way when user clicks on the item it won't open/close the accordion but instead perform the action you want to like openning a dropdown menu with more options.

Flexbox Accordions 
<div class="sui-accordion">

	<div class="sui-accordion-header">
		<div>Recommendation</div>
		<div>Score / 100</div>
		<div>Type</div>
	</div>

	<div class="sui-accordion-item">

		<div class="sui-accordion-item-header">
			<div class="sui-accordion-item-title"><i aria-hidden="true" class="sui-icon-warning-alert sui-error"></i> Item</div>
			<div><div class="sui-circle-score sui-grade-f" data-score="8"></div></div>
			<div>More info on something <button class="sui-button-icon sui-accordion-open-indicator" aria-label="Open item"><i class="sui-icon-chevron-down" aria-hidden="true"></i></button></div>
		</div>

		<div class="sui-accordion-item-body">
			<div class="sui-box">
				<div class="sui-box-body">
					<p>Item content – Hello!</p>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div>

</div>
Table Accordions 
<table class="sui-table sui-accordion">

	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th>Recommendation</th>
			<th>Score / 100</th>
			<th>Type</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>

	<tbody>

		<tr class="sui-accordion-item">
			<td class="sui-table-item-title"><i aria-hidden="true" class="sui-icon-warning-alert sui-error"></i> Item</td>
			<td><div class="sui-circle-score sui-grade-f" data-score="6"></div></td>
			<td>More info on something. <button class="sui-button-icon sui-accordion-open-indicator" aria-label="Expand"><i class="sui-icon-chevron-down" aria-hidden="true"></i></button></td>
		</tr>

		<tr class="sui-accordion-item-content">
			<td colspan="3">
				<div class="sui-box">
					<div class="sui-box-body">
						<p>Item content – Hello!</p>
					</div>
				</div>
			</td>
		</tr>

	</tbody>

</table>
Accordion Blocks 
<div class="sui-accordion sui-accordion-block">

	<div class="sui-accordion-item">

		<!-- Item header -->
		<div class="sui-accordion-item-header">

			<div class="sui-accordion-item-title sui-trim-title">Title <span class="sui-tag sui-tag-blue">Published</span></div>

			<div class="sui-accordion-item-date"><strong>Last Submission</strong> March 11, 2017 @ 10:18am</div>

			<div class="sui-accordion-col-auto">
				<button class="sui-button sui-button-ghost sui-accordion-item-action"><i class="sui-icon-pencil" aria-hidden="true"></i> Edit</button>
				<div class="sui-dropdown sui-accordion-item-action">
					<a href="#" class="sui-dropdown-anchor sui-icon-widget-settings-config" aria-label="Open Item Settings"></a>
					<ul>
						<li><a href=""><i class="sui-icon-eye" aria-hidden="true"></i> Preview</a></li>
						<li><a href=""><i class="sui-icon-community-people" aria-hidden="true"></i> View</a></li>
						<li><a href=""><i class="sui-icon-page-multiple" aria-hidden="true"></i> Duplicate</a></li>
						<li><a href=""><i class="sui-icon-cloud-migration" aria-hidden="true"></i> Export</a></li>
						<li><a href=""><i class="sui-icon-trash" aria-hidden="true"></i> Delete</a></li>
					</ul>
				</div>
				<button class="sui-button-icon sui-accordion-open-indicator" aria-label="Open Item"><i class="sui-icon-chevron-down" aria-hidden="true"></i></button>
			</div>

		</div>

		<!-- Item content -->
		<div class="sui-accordion-item-body">Your content goes here</div>

	</div>

</div>
Disabled Item Disable the row and prevent from opening.

Disable a flexbox accordion item:

<div class="sui-accordion-item"> ... </div>
<div class="sui-accordion-item"> ... </div>
<div class="sui-accordion-item sui-accordion-item--disabled"> ... </div>

Disable a table accordion item:

<tbody>
	<tr class="sui-accordion-item sui-accordion-item--disabled"> ... </tr>
	<tr class="sui-accordion-item-content"> ... </tr>
</tbody>

Tree Selectors

Most common uses are bulk selections of sub-options, and a file/directory browser.

Selector Mostly used as a tree structure for selection which options a user wants when there are nested options.
A good example is excluding tables from databases.

      • Sub Child Item

  • Parent / Single (Disabled)
Directory Browser Used for browsing and selecting files and folders. Most common use case can be found in Smush’s Directory Browsing feature.

Directory browser allows you to have a simple form to add extra folders. Search for the "+" button to try it.

Tree Selectors

Fancytree JS (Supported)

ONLY styles for fancy tree are supported. If you want to use fancy tree JS on your plugin, please read their documentation.

Click the checkbox to select an element, or click the arrow button to open/close tree sub-items.

Most common uses are bulk selections of sub-options, an a file/directory browser.

Selector Mostly used as a tree structure for selection which options a user wants when there are nested options.
A good example is excluding tables from databases.
Directory Browser Used for browsing and selecting files and folders. Most common use case can be found in Smush’s Directory Browsing feature.

Documentation

Simple Tree Find here the basics to make SUI Tree work correctly on your installation.
1. Initialize JS
Initialize JS 1. Get latest stable Shared UI release. 2. Load shared-ui.js on your plugin or trees.js file if you are using individual components. 3. SUI.suiTree() will initialize auto-magically on load, but if this doesn't happen you can initialize it on your installation by running the following script: 
$( function() {

	// Init SUI Tree
	if ( 0 !== $( 'SUI_BODY_CLASS .sui-tree' ).length ) {

		$( 'SUI_BODY_CLASS .sui-tree' ).each( function() {

			SUI.suiTree( $( this ), false );
		});
	}

}( jQuery ) );
2. Markup Selectors Tree
Starter Markup Here you will find two different base markups that will work with Simple Tree. Click on each tab to see more details. NOTE: Please pay attention to the notes I left in the sample code.
Basic Mode This markup uses only <span />'s inside <li /> reason why elements like checkboxes or buttons are handled with roles to make them correctly accessible for screen readers. 
<ul class="sui-tree" data-tree="selector" role="group">

	<li role="treeitem">

		<span class="sui-tree-node">

			<!-- Checkbox -->
			<span class="sui-node-checkbox" role="checkbox">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Select this item</span>
			</span>

			<!-- Text -->
			<span class="sui-node-text">Parent / Group</span>

			<!-- Button expander (for open/close) -->
			<span role="button" data-button="expander">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Open or close this item</span>
			</span>

		</span>

		<!-- NOTE:
			Wrap more items inside UL to create a new group inside parent item
		-->
		<ul role="group">

			<li role="treeitem">

				<span class="sui-tree-node">

					<!-- Checkbox -->
					<span class="sui-node-checkbox" role="checkbox">
						<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Select this item</span>
					</span>

					<!-- Text -->
					<span class="sui-node-text">Child Item</span>

					<!-- IMPORTANT:
						Notice expander button isn't here, this because it's not necessary.
						If for any case you can't remove the expander button from the markup
						don't worry because the JS function will check if item doesn't have
						child elements and will remove the expander button.
					-->

				</span>

			</li>

		</ul>

	</li>

</ul>

If you need to get the value assigned to checkbox, that must be retrieved using JS. For example, assign data-attribute="..." and check on change if li has aria-selected="true" attribute.

Complex Mode This markup uses <div />'s and other regular markup inside <li />. 
<ul class="sui-tree" data-tree="selector" role="group">

	<li role="treeitem">

		<div class="sui-tree-node">

			<!-- Checkbox -->
			<label for="unique-checkbox-id" class="sui-node-checkbox">
				<input
					type="checkbox"
					id="unique-checkbox-id"
				/>
				<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
				<span>Select this item</span>
			</label>

			<!-- Text -->
			<span class="sui-node-text">Parent / Group</span>

			<!-- Button expander (for open/close) -->
			<button data-button="expander">
				<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Open or close this item</span>
			</button>

		</div>

		<!-- NOTE:
			Wrap more items inside UL to create a new group inside parent item
		-->
		<ul role="group">

			<li role="treeitem">

				<div class="sui-tree-node">

					<!-- Checkbox -->
					<label for="unique-checkbox-id" class="sui-node-checkbox">
						<input
							type="checkbox"
							id="unique-checkbox-id"
						/>
						<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
						<span>Select this item</span>
					</label>

					<!-- Text -->
					<span class="sui-node-text">Child Item</span>

					<!-- IMPORTANT:
						Notice expander button isn't here, this because it's not necessary.
						If for any case you can't remove the expander button from the markup
						don't worry because the JS function will check if item doesn't have
						child elements and will remove the expander button.
					-->

				</div>

			</li>

		</ul>

	</li>

</ul>

If you need to get the value assigned to checkbox, that must be retrieved using JS. For example, assign data-attribute="..." and check on change if li has aria-selected="true" attribute.

3. Markup Directory Browser Tree

This markup supports complex mode markup variations mentioned on Selectors Tree markup.

Starter Markup This is the basic markup for directory browser tree and contains parent and child items. NOTE: Please pay attention to the notes I left in the sample code. 
<ul class="sui-tree" data-tree="directory" role="group">

	<li role="treeitem">

		<span class="sui-tree-node">

			<!-- Button expander (for open/close) -->
			<span role="button" data-button="expander">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Open or close this item</span>
			</span>

			<!-- Checkbox -->
			<span class="sui-node-checkbox" role="checkbox">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Select this item</span>
			</span>

			<!-- Icon -->
			<span aria-hidden="true"></span>

			<!-- Text -->
			<span class="sui-node-text">Parent / Group</span>

		</span>

		<!-- NOTE:
			Wrap more items inside UL to create a new group inside parent item
		-->
		<ul role="group">

			<li role="treeitem">

				<span class="sui-tree-node">

					<!-- IMPORTANT:
						Notice expander button isn't here, this because it's not necessary.
						If for any case you can't remove the expander button from the markup
						don't worry because the JS function will check if item doesn't have
						child elements and will remove the expander button.
					-->

					<!-- Checkbox -->
					<span class="sui-node-checkbox" role="checkbox">
						<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Select this item</span>
					</span>

					<!-- Icon -->
					<span aria-hidden="true"></span>

					<!-- Text -->
					<span class="sui-node-text">Child Item</span>

				</span>

			</li>

		</ul>

	</li>

</ul>
4. Tricks
1. Expand Item Add aria-expanded="true" to show parent item child elements on load. 
<li role="treeitem" aria-expanded="true"> ... </li>
2. Select Item Add aria-selected="true" to check an item on load. 
<li role="treeitem" aria-selected="true"> ... </li>
3. Disable Item Add aria-disabled="true" to disable an item and its childs. 
<li role="treeitem" aria-disabled="true"> ... </li>
4. Change Item Icon Add data-type=" ... " to change an item icon. Don't forget to replace ... with the type of icon you want to use.
Basic Icons 
<!-- TYPE: Page (Default icon for simple items) -->
<span data-type="page" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Folder (Default icon for parent items) -->
<span data-type="folder" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: PDF -->
<span data-type="pdf" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: ZIP -->
<span data-type="zip" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Image -->
<span data-type="image" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Padlock (locked) -->
<span data-type="lock" aria-hidden="true"></span>
Logo Icons 
<!-- TYPE: WPMU DEV Logo -->
<span data-type="wpmudev" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Defender Logo -->
<span data-type="defender" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Smush Logo -->
<span data-type="smush" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Hummingbird Logo -->
<span data-type="hummingbird" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Uptime Logo -->
<span data-type="uptime" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Smartcrawl Logo -->
<span data-type="smartcrawl" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Forminator Logo -->
<span data-type="forminator" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Shipper Logo -->
<span data-type="shipper" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Snapshot Logo -->
<span data-type="snapshot" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Hustle Logo -->
<span data-type="hustle" aria-hidden="true"></span>

<!-- TYPE: Performance Logo -->
<span data-type="performance" aria-hidden="true"></span>
5. Simple Form On Directory Browser Tree you can allow a parent item to add a new child item through a simple form.

Enable show/hide animation for the simple form by editing the tree function like this: SUI.suiTree( $( this ), true );

NOTE: This comes enabled by default from SUI but in case is not change above on the function might help you.

<ul class="sui-tree" data-tree="directory" role="group">

	<li role="treeitem">

		<span class="sui-tree-node">
			<span role="button" data-button="expander">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Open or close this item</span>
			</span>
			<span class="sui-node-checkbox" role="checkbox">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Select this item</span>
			</span>
			<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
			<span class="sui-node-text">Parent / Group</span>
			<span role="button" data-button="add">
				<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Add new folder</span>
			</span>
		</span>

		<ul role="group">

			<span role="contentinfo">

				<span id="label-unique-id" class="sui-screen-reader-text">Folder name</span>

				<span role="form">

					<input
						type="text"
						value=""
						placeholder="New folder name;"
						id="unique-id"
						aria-labelledby="label-unique-id"
					/>

					<span role="button">
						<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Add Folder</span>
					</span>

				</span>

				<span role="button" data-button="remove">
					<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Remove Folder</span>
				</span>

			</span>

			<!-- Already existing item -->
			<li role="treeitem">

				<span class="sui-tree-node">
					<span class="sui-node-checkbox" role="checkbox">
						<span class="sui-screen-reader-text">Select this item</span>
					</span>
					<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
					<span class="sui-node-text">Child Item</span>
				</span>

			</li>

		</ul>

	</li>

</ul>
Fancy Tree Find here the basics to make Fancy Tree JS with SUI styles work in your plugin.
1. Installation
Installation 1. Get latest Fancytree JS. Read their Wiki for correct steps. 2. Init Fancytree JS on your plugin: 
$( function() {

	// Init fancy tree
	$( '#tree-id' ).fancytree({
		// Put here all your settings
	});

}( jQuery ) );

In the showcase we use Fancytree JS 2.27.0 because latest available version 2.30.2 has an annoying bug that makes page scroll up or down when you click on an item.

2. Markup
Markup Selector Notice the class and attribute to load the correct styles for your tree. 
	<div
		id="tree-id"
		class="sui-tree-fancy"
		data-tree="selector"
	></div>
Markup Directory Browser Notice the class and attribute to load the correct styles for your tree. 
	<div
		id="tree-id"
		class="sui-tree-fancy"
		data-tree="directory"
	></div>
3. Tricks Fancytree JS
1. Enable / Disable Checkbox You can do this globally (for all checkboxes on tree) or per item. 
$( function() {

	$( '#tree-id' ).fancytree({

		// (Bool) global checkbox
		checkbox: false,

		// (Bool) Checkbox per item
		source: [
			{ title: 'Item', checkbox: true }
		],
	});

}( jQuery ) );
2. Expand Item Some times you need an item expanded and show its child items as soon as tree loads. 
$( function() {

	$( '#tree-id' ).fancytree({

		source: [
			{
				title: 'Item',
				expanded: true, // Expand item on load
				child: [ { title: 'Child Item' } ] // IMPORTANT: For expand to work correctly make sure you have child items
			}
		],
	});

}( jQuery ) );
3. Custom Icon When you use Directory Browser tree mode, notice each item have an icon (can be a folder or a page). To change the item icon follow this code example. 
$( function() {

	$( '#tree-id' ).fancytree({

		// Replace icon per item
		source: [
			{
				title: 'Item',
				icon: 'sui-icon-photo-picture' // Replace this with any SUI icon class
			}
		],

		// Replace folder icon (globally)
		icon: function( event, data ) {

			if ( data.node.isFolder() ) {
				return 'sui-icon-folder'; // Replace this with any SUI icon class.
			}
		},
	});

}( jQuery ) );
4. Remove Icons When you use Selectors tree mode, notice items don't have an icon. By default Fancytree JS enables these icons, you need to remove them to make it match the design. 
$( function() {

	$( '#tree-id' ).fancytree({

		// Remove icons (globally)
		icon: false,

	});

}( jQuery ) );

Scores

Animated gauges for scoring. Circles animate on page load.

If you are using individual js components, scores.js is required.

<div class="sui-circle-score sui-grade-f" data-score="10"></div>
<div class="sui-circle-score sui-grade-c" data-score="55"></div>
<div class="sui-circle-score sui-grade-a" data-score="95"></div>
<div class="sui-circle-score sui-circle-score-lg sui-grade-a" data-score="90"></div>

Dropdowns

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.

  • Samples
  • Documentation

Samples

Default Menu by default is right-aligned with the button.
  • External link
  • Link with icon
Left Menu Menu will be left-aligned with the button.
  • External link
  • Link with icon
Center Menu Menu will be center-aligned with the button.
  • External link
  • Link with icon

Documentation

If you are using SUI 2.3.2 or older version, you need to update the dropdown button markup when you upgrate to SUI 2.3.3.

If you are using individual js components, dropdowns.js is required.

Element Markup This is the correct markup to use for dropdown elements. 
<div class="sui-dropdown">
	<button class="sui-button-icon sui-dropdown-anchor" aria-label="Dropdown">
		<i class="sui-icon-widget-settings-config" aria-hidden="true"></i>
	</button>
	<ul>
		<li><button>CTA Button</button></li>
		<li><a href="http://external-link.com/" target="_blank">External link</a></li>
		<li><button><i class="sui-icon-trash" aria-hidden="true"></i> Button with icon</button></li>
	</ul>
</div>
Menu Variations There are some projects where the menu should display in different places.
In case you need the menu aligns to the left, you can make use of sui-dropdown-right class. For example: 
<div class="sui-dropdown sui-dropdown-right">
	<!-- The rest of the element goes here -->
</div>
In case you need the menu aligns to the middle, you can make use of sui-dropdown-center class. For example: 
<div class="sui-dropdown sui-dropdown-center">
	<!-- The rest of the element goes here -->
</div>

Radio

Used for inline field selection when only a few options are present. If that are enough options that it can take up a lot of space it may make more sense to use multiselect or select.

Inline A standard radio layout, placed next to eachoter.
Stacked A standard radio layout, stacked on top of one another.
Small
Radio Image

Checkbox

Used for inline field selection when only a few options are present. If that are enough options that it can take up a lot of space it may make more sense to use multiselect or select.

Inline A standard checkbox layout, placed next to eachoter.
Stacked A standard checkbox layout, stacked on top of one another.
Small
Checkbox Image

Select

Select A simple selector with a dropdown list.
Select2 jQuery based selector powered with a search field. Commonly user with long list of options. E.g. Countries list.
Multi Select Powered by Select2. This field is commonly used to allow user to select more than one option from a list, and to even include new options.

File Uploads

To be used when the user only needs to upload a general file, not image.

Default For use as a general file uploader that doesn’t require an image previewer.
Selected When the user has selected a file.
example-file.pdf
The user can click the whole block to change the file, or click the X to remove file.
Upload error When there is an issue uploading the file, or it’s the wrong file type.

Whoops, only .pdf and .doc filetypes are allowed.

Multi - Default When the user is allowed to upload multiple files.
Multi - Selected When files have been chosen we keep the button.
Note: The button copy can be changed to be more contextual.
example-file.pdf

		required />

Radio

This element allows two variations: stacked and small.

For stacked radios you need to use <label class="sui-radio sui-radio-stacked">. For small radios try with <label class="sui-radio sui-radio-sm">

<label for="demo-radio--option-one" class="sui-radio">
	<input type="radio"
		name="demo-radio--options"
		id="demo-radio--option-one" />
	<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
	<span>Radio label</span>
</label>
Checkbox

This element allows two variations: stacked and small.

For stacked checkboxes you need to use <label class="sui-checkbox sui-checkbox-stacked">. For small checkboxes try with <label class="sui-checkbox sui-checkbox-sm">

<label for="demo-checkbox--option-one" class="sui-checkbox">
	<input type="checkbox"
		id="demo-checkbox--option-one" />
	<span aria-hidden="true"></span>
	<span>Checkbox label</span>
</label>
Select

Select and Select2 elements have an small variation that you can get by adding sui-select-sm class.

<!-- Select -->
<select>
	<option>Option 1</option>
	<option>Option 2</option>
	<option>Option 3</option>
</select>

<!-- Select2 -->
<select class="sui-select">
	<option>Option 1</option>
	<option>Option 2</option>
	<option>Option 3</option>
</select>

Multi Select has a large variation that you can get by adding sui-select-lg class.

<!-- Select2: Multiple Select -->
<select class="sui-select"
	placeholder="Select an option"
	multiple>
	<option>Option 1</option>
	<option>Option 2</option>
	<option>Option 3</option>
</select>

jQuery UI – Calendar

The Shared UI supports styling of the jQuery UI datepicker but doesn't include the library so you will need to include that in your plugin yourself. To use the styles you will need to add the class sui-calendar to your datepicker element.

See code snippet below to see how it was done in this showcase.

$( '.sui-date .sui-form-control' ).datepicker({
		beforeShow: function( input, inst ) {
			$( '#ui-datepicker-div' ).addClass( 'sui-calendar' );
		},
		'dateFormat': 'd MM yy'
	});

Form Groups

When multiple inputs are stacked vertically, they should be wrapped in the .sui-form-field class to create vertical separation.

<div class="sui-box">
	<div class="sui-box-body">
		<div class="sui-form-field">
			<label for="demo-form-groups-text-1" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
			<input type="text" id="demo-form-groups-text-1" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
		</div>
		<div class="sui-form-field">
			<label for="demo-form-groups-text-2" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
			<input type="text" id="demo-form-groups-text-2" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
		</div>
		<div class="sui-form-field">
			<label for="demo-form-groups-text-3" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
			<input type="text" id="demo-form-groups-text-3" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
		</div>
	</div>
</div>

Form Layout

For multiple columns within a form, utilize the Shared UI grid system.

Input Sizes

Input fields have a default width of 100%.

To constrain the size of the input field you can add the following classes to either the sui-form-field or to the sui-form-control

sui-input-sm for a width of 80px, this is usually used when the expected input is 1 to 5 chars.

sui-input-md for a width of 240px, this is the standard size of an input when 100% is to wide.

You would use the sizing class in sui-form-field when there are other labels around the input that need to be constrained e.g. password input

This is a description about the field.

Example of using sui-input-sm in sui-form-control

<div class="sui-box">
	<div class="sui-box-body">
		<div class="sui-row">
			<div class="sui-col-sm-6">
				<div class="sui-form-field">
					<label for="demo-form-layout-text-1" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
					<input type="text" id="demo-form-layout-text-1" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
				</div>
			</div>
			<div class="sui-col-sm-6">
				<div class="sui-form-field">
					<label for="demo-form-layout-text-2" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
					<input type="text" id="demo-form-layout-text-2" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="sui-row">
			<div class="sui-col-sm-4">
				<div class="sui-form-field">
					<label for="demo-form-layout-text-3" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
					<input type="text" id="demo-form-layout-text-3" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
				</div>
			</div>
			<div class="sui-col-sm-8">
				<div class="sui-form-field">
					<label for="demo-form-layout-text-4" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
					<input type="text" id="demo-form-layout-text-4" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>

<!-- Input Sizes -->

	<label for="password1" class="sui-label">Password <a role="button" href="#" class="sui-label-link">Forgot Password</a></label>
	<div class="sui-password-group">
		<input type="password" id="password1" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type password" required>

Inline Errors

These error classes should be used when validating forms. Add the class.sui-form-field-error to the form-field or the direct parent wrapper of the input.
Note that the error message should be directly adjacent to the input. This means that if the field also has a description, the error message should be placed in between.

This is an error message!
This is an error message! This is a description about the field. 
<div class="sui-box">
	<div class="sui-box-body">

		<!-- text input -->
		<div class="sui-form-field">
			<label for="demo-input-error-text-1" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
			<input type="text" id="demo-input-error-text-1" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
		</div>

		<!-- text input with error -->
		<div class="sui-form-field sui-form-field-error">
			<label for="demo-input-error-text-2" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
			<input type="number" id="demo-input-error-text-2" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
			<span class="sui-error-message">This is an error message!</span>
		</div>

		<!-- text input with description and error -->
		<div class="sui-form-field sui-form-field-error">
			<label for="demo-input-error-text-3" class="sui-label">Input Label</label>
			<input type="number" id="demo-input-error-text-3" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
			<span class="sui-error-message">This is an error message!</span>
			<span class="sui-description">This is a description about the field.</span>
		</div>

	</div>
</div>

Recipient

Calum Brash calum.brash@incsub.com

Example of recipients used in an email notification setting

Email notifications Choose who you want to receive uptime email notifications when your website becomes unavailable.
Calum Brash calum.brash@incsub.com
Andy Crone andy.crone@incsub.com
We won’t notify you if your website becomes available again within the specified timeframe. All downtimes are still recorded in the downtime report, you just won’t get notified. 
<!-- Recipient -->
<div class="sui-recipient">
	<span class="sui-recipient-name">Calum Brash</span>
	<span class="sui-recipient-email">calum.brash@incsub.com</span>
	<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon"><i class="sui-icon-trash" aria-hidden="true"></i></button>
</div>
<!-- Recipients settings example -->
<div class="sui-box-settings-row">
	<div class="sui-box-settings-col-1">
		<span class="sui-settings-label">Email notifications</span>
		<span class="sui-description">Choose who you want to receive uptime email notifications when your website becomes unavailable.</span>
	</div>
	<div class="sui-box-settings-col-2">
		<label class="sui-toggle">
			<input type="checkbox" id="email-notification" checked>
			<span class="sui-toggle-slider"></span>
		</label>
		<label for="email-notification" class="sui-toggle-label">Send an email notification when this website goes down</label>
		<div class="sui-border-frame sui-toggle-content">
			<div class="sui-recipients">
				<div class="sui-recipient">
					<span class="sui-recipient-name">Calum Brash</span>
					<span class="sui-recipient-email">calum.brash@incsub.com</span>
					<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon"><i class="sui-icon-trash" aria-hidden="true"></i></button>
				</div>
				<div class="sui-recipient">
					<span class="sui-recipient-name">Andy Crone</span>
					<span class="sui-recipient-email">andy.crone@incsub.com</span>
					<button type="button" class="sui-button-icon"><i class="sui-icon-trash" aria-hidden="true"></i></button>
				</div>
			</div>
			<button class="sui-add-recipient sui-button sui-button-ghost"><i class="sui-icon-plus" aria-hidden="true"></i>Add Recipient</button>
			<label for="threshold" class="sui-label">Threshold</label>
			<select id="threshold" name="select-list">
				<option value="5" selected="selected">5 Minutes</option>
				<option value="10">10 Minutes</option>
			</select>
			<span class="sui-description">We won’t notify you if your website becomes available again within the specified timeframe. All downtimes are still recorded in the downtime report, you just won’t get notified.</span>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>

Summary

The summary is used to display a summary of the pages information.

Summary box variables has been updated on SUI 2.3.1. To load an image into summary box you need to use $summary-image: 'path-to-image';. For other variables like image size and position you can check _variables.scss file.

  • Small
  • Unbranded
  • Rebranded

Use sui-unbranded class when Hide WPMU DEV Branding settings are enabled but user didn't add any image or image is null.

  • Submissions in the last 30 days 1000

Use sui-rebranded class when Hide WPMU DEV Branding settings are enabled and user added an image. Make sure to add the image url as an inline background image for sui-summary-image-space div.

Documentation

Variables Depending on the project and the image size you gonna use for the Summary element, you gonna have to overwrite some base variables.   NOTE: Remember to include these variables on top of your file to call them correctly during build.
This element is set to have min-height: 212px, making it the most used through projects. 
// Set summary image
//
// NOTE: If you don't enter this variable, the image won't show on the summary.
$summary-image: 'path-to-plugin/assets/images/your-image.png';

// ========================================
// Overwrite image size
$summary-image--width:  192px;
$summary-image--height: 182px;

// ========================================
// Overwrite image position
$summary-image--position-x: 30px; // Horizontal position (only)
$summary-image--position-y: bottom; // Vertical position (only)
This element is set to have min-height: 151px, used mostly on projects that require a small resume to display, like Forminator's forms listings page. 
// Set small summary image
//
// NOTE: If you don't enter this variable and $summary-image exists,
// this image will show instead small summary image, but if none of them
// exist the image won't show on the summary.
$summary-image-sm: 'path-to-plugin/assets/images/your-small-image.png';

// Overwrite image size
$summary-image-sm--width:  192px;
$summary-image-sm--height: 121px;

// ========================================
// Overwrite image position
$summary-image-sm--position-x: 30px; // Horizontal position (only)
$summary-image-sm--position-y: bottom; // Vertical position (only)
Markup There's one base markup for the summary element with just a slight change based on the box size.

If you need a small summary you can add next to sui-summary a new class called sui-summary-sm.

<div class="sui-box sui-summary">

	<div class="sui-summary-image-space" aria-hidden="true"></div>

	<div class="sui-summary-segment">

		<div class="sui-summary-details">

			<span class="sui-summary-large">97</span>
			<i aria-hidden="true" class="sui-icon-info sui-warning"></i>
			<span class="sui-summary-percent">/100</span>
			<span class="sui-summary-sub">Current performance score</span>

			<span class="sui-summary-detail">December 12, 2017 at 1:46 am</span>
			<span class="sui-summary-sub">Last test</span>

		</div>

	</div>

	<div class="sui-summary-segment">

		<ul class="sui-list">

			<li>
				<span class="sui-list-label">Previous score</span>
				<span class="sui-list-detail">76</span>
			</li>

			<li>
				<span class="sui-list-label">Improvement</span>
				<span class="sui-list-detail"><span class="sui-tag sui-tag-error">-1</span></span>
			</li>

			<li>
				<span class="sui-list-label">Recommendations</span>
				<span class="sui-list-detail">4</span>
			</li>

		</ul>

	</div>

</div>

Tabs

If you are using individual js components, tabs.js is required.

If you add some tabs after the DOM has loaded you can initialise them by calling SUI.suiTabs();

  • Tabs
  • Side Tabs
  • Documentation

Tabs

Tabs can be used to add multiple content boxes into a smaller screen space.

Default The standard state for any tabs where they are already in a padded container.
Tab 1

Side Tabs

If you are using or want to use side tabs for radio input options after DOM has loaded, you can initialise them by calling SUI.sideTabs( this ); for each .sui-side-tabs label.sui-tab-item input element.

Side tabs are used more like a selector. They can used for yes/no, or more usually for choosing which option out of 2+ to choose from and then showing content for that choice.

Default Default tabs state, with no content - just a plain selector.
With Content This example shows how the selection made can show a block based on their selection.

Content for "Cover" tab.

Content for "Fill" tab.

Content for "Contain" tab.

Content for "None" tab.

Content for tabs "Cover" and "Contain".

Documentation

Default This is the markup required for standard tabs. 
<div class="sui-tabs">

	<div data-tabs>
		<div id="sui-tab-1" class="active">Tab 1</div>
		<div id="sui-tab-2" >Tab 2</div>
		<div id="sui-tab-3" >Tab 3</div>
		<div id="sui-tab-4" >Tab 4</div>
	</div>

	<div data-panes>

		<div class="active"><p>Content. Tab 1.</p></div>
		<div><p>Content. Tab 2.</p></div>
		<div><p>Content. Tab 3.</p></div>
		<div><p>Content. Tab 4.</p></div>

	</div>

</div>

You will note the ids for each of the data-tabs; this is not required but if you want a specific tab to be opened on page load by a hash value you will need them.

Flushed For using inside modals or boxes where they are in a padded container but need to be flush to the top and sides. 
<div class="sui-tabs sui-tabs-flushed">

	...

</div>
Side Tabs 
<div class="sui-side-tabs sui-tabs">

	<div data-tabs>
		<div class="active">Tab 1</div>
		<div>Tab 2</div>
		<div>Tab 3</div>
		<div>Tab 4</div>
	</div>

	<div data-panes>
		<div class="sui-tab-boxed active"><p>Content. Tab 1.</p></div>
		<div class="sui-tab-boxed"><p>Content. Tab 2.</p></div>
		<div class="sui-tab-boxed"><p>Content. Tab 3.</p></div>
		<div class="sui-tab-boxed"><p>Content. Tab 4.</p></div>
	</div>

</div>
Advanced Usage 
SUI.suiTabs({
    tabGroup: '[data-tabs]',
    paneGroup: '[data-panes]',
    tabActive: 'active',
    paneActive: 'active',
    callback: function(tab, pane) {
      console.log(tab);
      console.log(pane);
    });

tabGroup and paneGroup

  • tabGroup is the selector of the direct parent of the tabs.
  • paneGroup is the selector of the direct parent of the panes.

tabActive and paneActive

  • tabActive is the classname that will be set when the tab is active.
  • paneActive is the classname that will be set when the pane is active.

callback

It's an anonymous function that will run when you click a tab. You will have access to the clicked tab and the respective pane.

To get all tabs within the group you can do this inside the anonymous function:

console.log(tab.parentNode.children);
console.log(pane.parentNode.children);

Top Notifications

The top notifications have a different styling and are fixed. They use the class .sui-notice-top or .sui-notice-floating in the parent class instead of .sui-notice. You will see an example of how the top notification looks when you refresh this page.

The default sui-notice-top notification will automatically hide after 3 seconds. If you prefer the user to hide the notification themselves you can add .sui-can-dismiss to the parent div and add a dismiss button to the notice shown in the code sample below.

If you don't want the notice dismissed at all you can add .sui-cant-dismiss to the parent div.

Below are examples of both the sui-notice-top and the sui-notice-floating (floating with button)

You can override the icon with the following code

p:first-of-type {
	@include icon(before, update)
}
// Top notice with button.
<div class="sui-notice-top sui-notice-success sui-can-dismiss">
	<p><strong>Notice success:</strong> Page caching is currently active.</p>
	<span class="sui-notice-dismiss">
		<a role="button" href="#" aria-label="Dismiss" class="sui-icon-check"></a>
	</span>
</div>
// Floating notice with button.
<div class="sui-notice-floating sui-notice-info">
	<p>You've made changes to your file structure</p>
	<div class="sui-notice-buttons">
		<button href="#" class="sui-button sui-button-blue"><i class="sui-icon-web-globe-world" aria-hidden="true"></i>Publish</button>
	</div>
</div>

Tooltips

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.

  • Basic
  • Special Cases
  • Documentation
Default Tooltips will appear to top of the element and center aligned to it.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with top-center alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with top-center alignment.
Top Left Tooltips will appear to top of the element and stick to left of it.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with top-left alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with top-left alignment.
Top Right Tooltips will appear to top of the element and stick to right of it.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with top-right alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with top-right alignment.
Bottom Tooltips will appear to bottom of the element and center aligned to it.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with bottom-center alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with bottom-center alignment.
Bottom Left Tooltips will appear to bottom of the element and stick to left of it.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with bottom-left alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with bottom-left alignment.
Bottom Right Tooltips will appear to bottom of the element and stick to right of it.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with bottom-right alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with bottom-right alignment.
Right Tooltips will appear to right side of the element.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with center-right alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with center-right alignment.
Left Tooltips will appear to left side of the element.
Regular This is a sample of regular tooltips with center-left alignment.
Constrained This is a sample of constrained tooltips with center-left alignment.
There are times when you need a top-center tooltip displayed on desktops, but on small screens content is being cut-off.
You can add sui-tooltip-mobile to keep original position but constrain content on small screens only.
You can add sui-tooltip-{position}-mobile to re-position your tooltip on small screens only.

Remember to replace {position} with: top, top-left, top-right, bottom, bottom-left, bottom-right, left, or right.

There are times when you need a 171px tooltip but constrained tooltips width is set to 240px by default.
You can add --tooltip-width: 171px as inline style and this will be applied to tooltips only.
Base Structure Tooltips are simple, you just need the base structure and add extra classes for special alignment. 
<!-- Base Structure -->
<div class="sui-tooltip"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>
Variations Sample code to position your tooltips based on design requirements.
In case you have some doubts on what you need, go to "Samples" tab and take a look at the different tooltip variations. 
<!-- POSITION: Top Center -->
<div class="sui-tooltip"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-top"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Top Left -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-top-left"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Top Right -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-top-right"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Bottom Center -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-bottom"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Bottom Left -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-bottom-left"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Bottom Right -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-bottom-right"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Center Left -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-left"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>

<!-- POSITION: Center Right -->
<div class="sui-tooltip sui-tooltip-right"
	data-tooltip="Tooltip content goes here">
	Element content
</div>
Constrained There are cases when you need tooltips with an specific width. 
<!-- Constrained: Default Width -->
<button class="sui-button sui-constrained"
	data-tooltip="">
	Default
</button>

<!-- Constrained: Custom Width -->
<button class="sui-button sui-constrained"
	style="--tooltip-width: 170px;"
	data-tooltip="">
	Default
</button>
Special Fixes You can further modify tooltips using the following inline styles. 
<!-- Tooltips Width -->
<button class="sui-button"
	style="--tooltip-width: 170px;"
	data-tooltip="">
	Default
</button>

<!-- Tooltips Width (Small Screens Only) -->
<button class="sui-button sui-button-mobile"
	style="--tooltip-width-mobile: 170px;"
	data-tooltip="">
	Default
</button>

<!-- Tooltips Text Align -->
<button class="sui-button"
	style="--tooltip-text-align: left;"
	data-tooltip="">
	Default
</button>

Icons

All icons are prefixed with .sui-icon-.

Example: 
<i class="sui-icon-wpmudev-logo" aria-hidden="true"></i>

The following icons are available. Click icon to copy markup to clipboard.

Icon Sizes

The default size of an icon is the same as its parent element. For more specific sizes, you can choose from the following:

<!-- Small -->
<i class="sui-icon-wpmudev-logo sui-sm" aria-hidden="true"></i>

<!-- Medium -->
<i class="sui-icon-wpmudev-logo sui-md" aria-hidden="true"></i>

<!-- Large -->
<i class="sui-icon-wpmudev-logo sui-lg" aria-hidden="true"></i>

<!-- Extra Large -->
<i class="sui-icon-wpmudev-logo sui-xl" aria-hidden="true"></i>

Fixed Width Icons

Use .sui-fw to set icons at a fixed width. Great to use when different icon widths throw off alignment. Especially useful in things like nav lists & list groups.

  • Hummingbird
  • Code
  • Defender
<ul>
	<li><i class="sui-icon-hummingbird sui-fw" aria-hidden="true"></i> Hummingbird</li>
	<li><i class="sui-icon-code sui-fw" aria-hidden="true"></i> Code</li>
	<li><i class="sui-icon-defender sui-fw" aria-hidden="true"></i> Defender</li>
</ul>

Animated Icons

You can infinitely spin an icon by adding the .sui-loading class.

<i class="sui-icon-loader sui-loading" aria-hidden="true"></i>

Status Dot

Commonly used on Dashboard or Listings pages to let user's know if an element is active or not.

Dialogs

Dialogs are streamlined, but flexible, dialog prompts with the minimum required functionality.

  • Default
  • Alternative
  • On Boarding
  • Documentation

Default Dialog

This dialog can come in two different sizes: default and large.

Currently is not possible to have a small version of this dialog.

Alternative Dialog

Alternative dialogs differ from default ones in two main things: it's content is center aligned, header and footer doesn't have any border to visually split them from body content.

It can be used in three different modes (or cases):

Commonly used on dialogs to delete an element or confirm an action. There are some cases when are accompanied by a footer image.

This kind of dialog is commonly used for integrations settings or in cases where we need to highlight the image of the product we're editing.

On Boarding

This dialog comes in one size (500px maximum width).

Documentation

If you are using individual js components, dialog.js and a11y-dialog.js are both required.

Dialogs are streamlined, but flexible, dialog prompts with the minimum required functionality.

We use the library A11y-Dialog to make sure they're accessible as possible.

Any dialogs with the class sui-dialog will be instantiated and stored in SUI.dialogs with their id. You will be able to call methods on these instances e.g. SUI.dialogs['my-accessible-dialog'].hide() will hide the corresponding dialog with the id my-accessible-dialog.

Javascript Instantiation 
// Get the dialog element (with the accessor method you want)
const el = document.getElementById('my-accessible-dialog');

// Instantiate a new A11yDialog module
const dialog = new A11yDialog(el);
DOM API

The following button will open the dialog with the my-accessible-dialog id when interacted with.

<button type="button" data-a11y-dialog-show="my-accessible-dialog">Open the dialog</button>

The following button will hide the dialog with the my-accessible-dialog id when interacted with.

<button type="button" data-a11y-dialog-hide>Close the dialog</button>
JS API

Regarding the JS API, it simply consists on show() and hide() methods on the dialog instance.

// Show the dialog
dialog.show();

// Hide the dialog
dialog.hide();
Changing Animations

See example below changing the animation to fade instead of bounce for the modal with id my-accessible-dialog.

Note: You will have run this code after the dialog has been instantiated.

// Change animation on the show event
SUI.dialogs['my-accessible-dialog'].on( 'show', function( dialogEl, event ) {
	var content = dialogEl.getElementsByClassName( 'sui-dialog-content' );
	content[0].className = 'sui-dialog-content sui-fade-in';
});

// Change animation on the hide event
SUI.dialogs['my-accessible-dialog'].on( 'hide', function( dialogEl, event ) {
	var content = dialogEl.getElementsByClassName( 'sui-dialog-content' );
	content[0].className = 'sui-dialog-content sui-fade-out';
});

The following code snippet is an example of the dialog code.

<div class="sui-dialog" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1" id="my-accessible-dialog">

	<div class="sui-dialog-overlay" data-a11y-dialog-hide></div>

	<div class="sui-dialog-content" aria-labelledby="dialogTitle" aria-describedby="dialogDescription" role="dialog">

		<div class="sui-box" role="document">

			<div class="sui-box-header">
				<h3 class="sui-box-title" id="dialogTitle">Dialog Title</h3>
				<div class="sui-actions-right">
					<button data-a11y-dialog-hide class="sui-dialog-close" aria-label="Close this dialog window"></button>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="sui-box-body">
				<p id="dialogDescription">Fill in the ridiculously small form below to receive our ridiculously cool newsletter!</p>
				<div class="sui-row">
					<div class="sui-col">
						<div class="sui-form-field">
							<label for="dialog-text-5" class="sui-label">Text</label>
							<input type="text" id="dialog-text-5" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
						</div>
					</div>
					<div class="sui-col">
						<div class="sui-form-field">
							<label for="dialog-text-6" class="sui-label">Text</label>
							<input type="text" id="dialog-text-6" class="sui-form-control" placeholder="input type text">
						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="sui-box-footer sui-space-between">
				<button class="sui-button" data-a11y-dialog-hide="my-accessible-dialog">Cancel</button>
				<button class="sui-modal-close sui-button sui-button-blue">Add</button>
			</div>

		</div>

	</div>

</div>

WP Editor

You will either need to use dist/css/sui-wp-editor.min.css or compile scss/sui-wp-editor.scss to use the SUI WP Editor styles within your plugin.

The following code snippet is a sample on how to call the file on wp_editor.

<?php
ob_start();

require self::$plugin_path . 'assets/css/sui-editor.min.css';
$editor_css = ob_get_clean();
$editor_css = '<style>' . $editor_css. '</style>';
?>

<!-- Email body -->
<div class="sui-form-field">

	<label class="sui-label sui-label-editor" for="emailmessage"><?php esc_html_e( 'Email body', Opt_In::TEXT_DOMAIN ); ?></label>

	<?php wp_editor(
		$email['email_body'],
		'emailmessage',
		array(
			'media_buttons'    => false,
			'textarea_name'    => 'email_message',
			'editor_css'       => $editor_css,
			'tinymce'          => array(
				'content_css' => self::$plugin_url . 'assets/css/sui-editor.min.css'
			),
			'editor_height'    => 192,
			'drag_drop_upload' => false,
		)
	); ?>

	<span class="sui-description"><?php esc_html_e( 'Use the placeholder {hustle_unsubscribe_link} to insert the unsubscription link.', Opt_In::TEXT_DOMAIN ); ?></span>

</div>

Branded Footer This element is used on all plugins: pro and free versions. 
<div class="sui-footer">Made with <i class="sui-icon-heart"></i> by WPMU DEV</div>
Footer Navigation All footers should include navigation after Branded Footer.

Notice Support link on sample says "plugin-name" and should be replaced with the correct name assigned to the developed project on wp.org.

<!-- FREE Navigation -->
<ul class="sui-footer-nav">
	<li><a href="https://profiles.wordpress.org/wpmudev#content-plugins" target="_blank">Free Plugins</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://premium.wpmudev.org/features/" target="_blank">Membership</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://premium.wpmudev.org/roadmap/" target="_blank">Roadmap</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://wordpress.org/support/plugin/plugin-name" target="_blank">Support</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://premium.wpmudev.org/docs/" target="_blank">Docs</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://premium.wpmudev.org/hub-welcome/" target="_blank">The Hub</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://premium.wpmudev.org/terms-of-service/" target="_blank">Terms of Service</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://incsub.com/privacy-policy/" target="_blank">Privacy Policy</a></li>
</ul>

Cross-Sell Banners This element is used on free plugins to promote our top products available on WordPress.
Markup 
<!-- Have in mind you can have a max of 3 banners in the footer -->

<div class="sui-cross-1">
	<span></span>
</div>
SCSS File 
// Cross-sell Banners
// In lowercase insert the name of the plugin you want to promote.

$cross-sell-1: 'smush';
$cross-sell-2: 'defender';
$cross-sell-3: 'smartcrawl';
Cross Sell This footer will be included at the bottom of free plugin's Dashboard page to promote our top products.

	<h3>Check out our other free wordpress.org plugins!</h3>

  • Basic Tour

    In this example, we allow the user to go back and forth between screens and provide basic controls. This is most likely how onboarding tutorials will be.

    Skip this, I know my way around

  • Example Step

    Ok so this is the first step in the experience. The user can close the modal, or go to the previous screen via the buttons up top. The primary action is to proceed using the button. All of this works well on mobile too.

    Skip this, I'll create a module later

  • Last Step

    In the final step, we change the button back to blue to subconsciously highlight that it’s a final step. In this example, the user can still go back if they want to.

    Skip this, I'll create a module later

  • First Step

    Ok so this is the first step in the experience. The user can close the modal to cancel the flow but the primary action is to proceed using the button. These will usually be user triggered actions like adding a new module.

    Skip this, I know my way around

  • Last Step

    In the final step, we change the button back to blue to subconsciously highlight that it’s a final step. In this example the user is unable to go back and must proceed.

    Skip this, I'll create a module later
